#Summary1=(human1) Author Cory Doctorow gives advice on how to be productive and get writing done despite distractions from the Internet such as IM or email by keeping a short, regular work schedule of at least 20 minutes of work daily, leaving oneself a 'rough edge' of unfinished work to resume the next day, not expecting a perfect work environment, and turning off realtime communication tools.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Cory Doctorow argues that while the internet can be distracting, writers can successfully manage their online time and creative work through simple techniques like maintaining a short daily writing schedule, leaving unfinished edges in their work, avoiding ceremony, and eliminating real-time communication tools.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) Cory Doctorow argues that rather than avoiding the Internet, writers should embrace it and manage distractions through techniques like short, consistent writing sessions, setting daily goals, avoiding real-time communication interruptions, and not waiting for the perfect environment, to maintain productivity and creativity.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Author Cory Doctorow shares personal techniques for balancing writing with distractions, emphasizing the importance of setting a regular work schedule, leaving a rough edge, and avoiding real-time communications tools to maintain focus.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) To combat distractions and maintain productivity as a writer in the digital age, establish a consistent, limited work schedule, create a "rough edge" by stopping mid-sentence each day, and minimize interruptions from technology.
#Text=Writing in the Age of Distraction
#Text=By Cory Doctorow
#Text=#argument , #systemanalysis #cognitivebias #analysis #sharedvalues #advice #langu age #writinglife
#Text=“ Distractions ” by Emily boston is licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0

#Text=We know that our readers are distracted and sometimes even overwhelmed by the myriad distractions that lie one click away on the Internet , but of course writers face the same glorious problem : the delirious world of information and communication and community that lurks behind your screen , one alt - tab away from your word - processor .
#Text=The single worst piece of writing advice I ever got was to stay away from the Internet because it would only waste my time and would n’t help my writing .
#Text=This advice was wrong creatively , professionally , artistically , and personally , but I know where the writer who doled it out was coming from .

#Text=Every now and again , when I see a new website , game , or service , I sense the tug of an attention black hole : a time - sink that is just waiting to fill my every discretionary moment with distraction .

#Text=As a co-parenting new father who writes at least a book per year , half - a - dozen columns a month , ten or more blog posts a day , plus assorted novellas and stories and speeches , I know just how short time can be and how dangerous distraction is .
#Text=But the Internet has been very good to me .
#Text=It ’s informed my creativity and aesthetics , it ’s benefited me professionally and personally , and for every moment it steals , it gives back a hundred delights .
#Text=I ’d no sooner give it up than I ’d give up fiction or any other pleasurable vice .
#Text=I think I ’ve managed to balance things out through a few simple techniques that I ’ve been refining for years .
#Text=I still sometimes feel frazzled and info - whelmed , but that ’s rare .
#Text=Most of the time , I ’m on top of my workload and my muse .
#Text=Here ’s how I do it :
#Text=Short , regular work schedule
#Text=When I ’m working on a story or novel , I set a modest daily goal — usually a page or two — and then I meet it every day , doing nothing else while I ’m working on it .
#Text=It ’s not plausible or desirable to try to get the world to go away for hours at a time , but it ’s entirely possible to make it all shut up for 20 minutes .
#Text=Writing a page every day gets me more than a novel per year — do the math — and there ’s always 20 minutes to be found in a day , no matter what else is going on .
#Text=Twenty minutes is a short enough interval that it can be claimed from a sleep or meal - break ( though this should n’t become a habit ) .
#Text=The secret is to do it every day , weekends included , to keep the momentum going , and to allow your thoughts to wander to your next day ’s page between sessions .
#Text=Try to find one or two vivid sensory details to work into the next page , or a bon mot , so that you ’ve already got some material when you sit down at the keyboard .
#Text=Leave yourself a rough edge
#Text=When you hit your daily word - goal , stop .
#Text=Stop even if you ’re in the middle of a sentence .
#Text=Especially if you ’re in the middle of a sentence .
#Text=That way , when you sit down at the keyboard the next day , your first five or ten words are already ordained , so that you get a little push before you begin your work .
#Text=Knitters leave a bit of yarn sticking out of the day ’s knitting so they know where to pick up the next day — they call it the “ hint . ”
#Text=Potters leave a rough edge on the wet clay before they wrap it in plastic for the night — it ’s hard to build on a smooth edge .
#Text=Do n’t be ceremonious
#Text=Forget advice about finding the right atmosphere to coax your muse into the room .
#Text=Forget candles , music , silence , a good chair , a cigarette , or putting the kids to sleep .

#Text=It ’s nice to have all your physical needs met before you write , but if you convince yourself that you can only write in a perfect world , you compound the problem of finding 20 free minutes with the problem of finding the right environment at the same time .
#Text=When the time is available , just put fingers to keyboard and write .
#Text=You can put up with noise / silence / kids / discomfort / hunger for 20 minutes .
#Text=Realtime communications tools are deadly
#Text=The biggest impediment to concentration is your computer ’s ecosystem of interruption technologies : IM , email alerts , RSS alerts , Skype rings , etc.
#Text=Anything that requires you to wait for a response , even subconsciously , occupies your attention .
#Text=Anything that leaps up on your screen to announce something new , occupies your attention .

#Text=The more you can train your friends and family to use email , message boards , and similar technologies that allow you to save up your conversation for planned sessions instead of demanding your attention right now helps you carve out your 20 minutes .

#Text=By all means , schedule a chat — voice , text , or video — when it ’s needed , but leaving your IM running is like sitting down to work after hanging a giant “ DISTRACT ME ” sign over your desk , one that shines brightly enough to be seen by the entire world .
#Text=I do n’t claim to have invented these techniques , but they ’re the ones that have made the 21st century a good one for me .
